message_1: A sample of carbon-14 has an initial activity of 50 disintegrations per minute (dpm). If the half-life of carbon-14 is 5730 years, what will be the activity of the sample after 17,190 years?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the radioactive decay formula:

Activity_final = Activity_initial * (1/2)^(time_elapsed / half_life)

where Activity_final is the activity of the sample after 17,190 years, Activity_initial is the initial activity (50 dpm), time_elapsed is the time passed (17,190 years), and half_life is the half-life of carbon-14 (5730 years).

Activity_final = 50 * (1/2)^(17,190 / 5730)

First, we need to find the number of half-lives that have passed:

17,190 / 5730 = 3

Now, we can plug this value back into the formula:

Activity_final = 50 * (1/2)^3

Activity_final = 50 * (1/8)

Activity_final = 6.25 dpm

So, the activity of the sample after 17,190 years will be approximately 6.25 disintegrations per minute.
